payload.instructions:
# Hearthlink Agent Team Manifest

This document defines the structure of the specialized AI agent team for the Hearthlink project. Each agent has a distinct role and is configured with a specific skill prompt from the `.claude/skills/` directory.

## Core Development Team

### 1. Specifications Planner
- **Role:** Gathers requirements, defines project scope, and produces detailed technical specifications (PRDs).
- **Skill File:** [.claude/skills/project-planner.md](./.claude/skills/project-planner.md)

### 2. System Architect
- **Role:** Designs the overall system architecture, including security, performance, and database structure.
- **Skill File:** [.claude/skills/system-architect.md](./.claude/skills/system-architect.md)

### 3. Agent Architect
- **Role:** Specializes in the design of the multi-agent ecosystem, communication, and coordination.
- **Skill File:** [.claude/skills/agent-architect.md](./.claude/skills/agent-architect.md)

### 4. Frontend Developer
- **Role:** Implements the UI/UX in React/TypeScript, focusing on accessibility and performance.
- **Skill File:** [.claude/skills/hearthlink-frontend-dev.md](./.claude/skills/hearthlink-frontend-dev.md)

### 5. Backend Developer
- **Role:** Implements the core services and IPC architecture in Rust/Tauri.
- **Skill File:** [.claude/skills/hearthlink-backend-dev.md](./.claude/skills/hearthlink-backend-dev.md)

## Specialist & Support Roles

### 6. UI/UX Design Specialist
- **Role:** Focuses on visual design, motion, and creating polished, intuitive interfaces.
- **Skill File:** [.claude/skills/hearthlink-ui-ux-designer.md](./.claude/skills/hearthlink-ui-ux-designer.md)

### 7. DevOps Engineer
- **Role:** Manages CI/CD pipelines, build automation, and infrastructure.
- **Skill File:** [.claude/skills/devops-engineer.md](./.claude/skills/devops-engineer.md)

### 8. Accessibility Specialist
- **Role:** Audits for WCAG compliance and ensures the application is inclusive.
- **Skill File:** [.claude/skills/accessibility-specialist.md](./.claude/skills/accessibility-specialist.md)

### 9. Voice Integration Specialist
- **Role:** Designs and implements voice interfaces, speech recognition, and TTS.
- **Skill File:** [.claude/skills/voice-integration-specialist.md](./.claude/skills/voice-integration-specialist.md)

### 10. Quality Validator (Code Reviewer)
- **Role:** Ensures code quality, test coverage, and requirement fulfillment through comprehensive code review and testing validation.
- **Skill File:** [.claude/skills/code-reviewer.md](./.claude/skills/code-reviewer.md)

### 11. Documentation Scribe
- **Role:** Creates and maintains comprehensive documentation including API references, user guides, architecture docs, and code comments.
- **Skill File:** [.claude/skills/documentation-scribe.md](./.claude/skills/documentation-scribe.md)

# Hearthlink Agent Team Manifest

This document defines the structure of the specialized AI agent team for the Hearthlink project. Each agent has a distinct role and is configured with a specific skill prompt from the `.claude/skills/` directory.

## Core Development Team

### 1. Specifications Planner
- **Role:** Gathers requirements, defines project scope, and produces detailed technical specifications (PRDs).

### 2. System Architect
- **Role:** Designs the overall system architecture, including security, performance, and database structure.
- **Skill File:** [.claude/skills/system-architect.md](./.claude/skills/system-architect.md)

### 3. Agent Architect
- **Role:** Specializes in the design of the multi-agent ecosystem, communication, and coordination.
- **Skill File:** [.claude/skills/agent-architect.md](./.claude/skills/agent-architect.md)

### 4. Frontend Developer
- **Role:** Implements the UI/UX in React/TypeScript, focusing on accessibility and performance.
- **Skill File:** [.claude/skills/hearthlink-frontend-dev.md](./.claude/skills/hearthlink-frontend-dev.md)

### 5. Backend Developer
- **Role:** Implements the core services and IPC architecture in Rust/Tauri.
- **Skill File:** [.claude/skills/hearthlink-backend-dev.md](./.claude/skills/hearthlink-backend-dev.md)

## Specialist & Support Roles

### 6. UI/UX Design Specialist
- **Role:** Focuses on visual design, motion, and creating polished, intuitive interfaces.
- **Skill File:** [.claude/skills/hearthlink-ui-ux-designer.md](./.claude/skills/hearthlink-ui-ux-designer.md)

### 7. DevOps Engineer
- **Role:** Manages CI/CD pipelines, build automation, and infrastructure.
- **Skill File:** [.claude/skills/devops-engineer.md](./.claude/skills/devops-engineer.md)

### 8. Accessibility Specialist
- **Role:** Audits for WCAG compliance and ensures the application is inclusive.
- **Skill File:** [.claude/skills/accessibility-specialist.md](./.claude/skills/accessibility-specialist.md)

### 9. Voice Integration Specialist
- **Role:** Designs and implements voice interfaces, speech recognition, and TTS.
- **Skill File:** [.claude/skills/voice-integration-specialist.md](./.claude/skills/voice-integration-specialist.md)

### 10. Quality Validator (Code Reviewer)
- **Role:** Ensures code quality, test coverage, and requirement fulfillment through comprehensive code review and testing validation.
- **Skill File:** [.claude/skills/code-reviewer.md](./.claude/skills/code-reviewer.md)

### 11. Documentation Scribe
- **Role:** Creates and maintains comprehensive documentation including API references, user guides, architecture docs, and code comments.
- **Skill File:** [.claude/skills/documentation-scribe.md](./.claude/skills/documentation-scribe.md)
</INSTRUCTIONS>

payload.text:
**Reviewing Git branches and merge priorities**

I’m analyzing remote branches not merged into main and summarizing their features to help decide which to merge soon and which to hold off. I’ll flag branches like `consolidate-all-fixes` and `feature/enterprise-monitoring` as ready for merging due to critical fixes and features, while cautioning on others like `NOV16`, `October-Sprint`, and some enterprise-feature branches because they’re redundant or incomplete. I’ll also note local uncommitted changes and the lack of test runs, then lay out next step suggestions accordingly.

payload.message:
Refreshed from `origin` and inspected `git branch -r --no-merged origin/main` to see which branches are still ahead (plus the amber `git status -sb` shows my working tree on `NOV18` has uncommitted edits in `config/agents/manifest.json`, `config/skills/registry.json`, and `src/components/OnboardingWizard.tsx`, so keep those changes clean before any merge).

- **Need Merge**: `origin/consolidate-all-fixes` is the most urgent; it delivers the Tauri v2 migration, CI/Windows checkout stability work, and Rust/security/AI infrastructure fixes that are currently missing from `main`. `origin/feature/enterprise-monitoring` (and by extension the enterprise-focused feature set) brings multi-user, RBAC/ABAC, SIEM, and monitoring modules plus documentation, so it should be merged as soon as the enterprise release window is agreed. `origin/work` adds the PersonaMemoryBridge integration and accompanying tests, which looks production ready once the new modules are exercised. `origin/NOV18`, which is my current branch, also contains the onboarding/wizard/UI refinements and the huge set of agent docs/assets; merge it after reviewing the massive diff and ensuring those new files comply with any licensing or data-size expectations.

- **Hold Off**: `origin/NOV16` and `origin/October-Sprint` are superseded by `NOV18` (same commits plus tweaks) and don’t need separate merges—bringing them in would only reintroduce unchanged history. The other enterprise-named branches (`feature/enterprise-multi-user`, `feature/enterprise-rbac-abac`, `feature/enterprise-siem`) point to similar earlier commits; coordinate whether they should be merged individually or if the single `feature/enterprise-monitoring` branch already covers those deliverables before landing anything else.

Tests were not run (no merges performed).

Next steps:
1. Merge `origin/consolidate-all-fixes` into `main`, run the CI pipeline, and resolve any Tauri/build regressions it raises.
2. Once enterprise feature QA is green, merge `origin/feature/enterprise-monitoring` (and then drop the redundant enterprise sub-branches if they are stale).
3. Review the `NOV18` diff (especially the influx of `.chatgpt/Claude` assets) before merging, and finish committing the local edits so the working tree stays clean.

- **Agent Suggestion:** Proactively recommends agents/participants (personas, plugins, external) based on current context or performance trends, but never activates without user command.
- **Breakout Rooms:** User can create topic-specific sessions (“breakout rooms”)—all participation is visible and logged.
- **Context Mediation:** Manages all agent requests, ensures context handoff and moderation is clear and recoverable.

---

## Technical Architecture

- **Session Registry:**\
  Tracks all live and archived sessions, including participants, logs, and outcomes.\
  Supports instant join/leave and full session restoration for ongoing collaborations.
- **Room Management:**\
  Users create/destroy rooms, select participants, define topics.\
  Core only facilitates connections—never accesses or mutates persona memory directly (see Vault for cross-persona policy).
- **Live Feed and Logging:**\
  All prompts, responses, and agent actions are streamed to a live session feed.\
  All events, including suppressed agent responses, are captured in the log (hidden from live feed if not included in user-facing conversation).
- **External Agent Handling:**\
  External agents (via Synapse) are shown as equal participants, but can only join/leave at user direction.\
  All external engagement is fully logged and auditable.
- **Audit & Recovery:**\
  Every room/session/agent join/leave/action is timestamped, logged, and exportable.

---

---

## **API Contracts**

- `POST /api/core/session` — Create new session/room (define topic, participants)
- `PATCH /api/core/session/:id/participants` — Add/remove agent or external participant
- `POST /api/core/session/:id/breakout` — Create breakout room (subset of participants)
- `GET /api/core/session/:id/log` — Export session, room, or live feed log
- `PATCH /api/core/session/:id/settings` — Update live feed verbosity, log detail, or export policy
- `DELETE /api/core/session/:id` — End and archive session

**All endpoints require user authentication/authorization and are logged/audited.**

---


`type CoreSessionProps = { roomId: string topic: string participants: Participant[] sessionLog: SessionEvent[] breakouts: BreakoutRoom[] liveFeedSettings: LiveFeedSettings onParticipantChange: (participants: Participant[]) => void onBreakoutCreate: (breakout: BreakoutRoom) => void onLogExport: () => void onSessionEnd: () => void auditLog: AuditEvent[] }`

- **Room/Session Management:**\
  User can add/remove agents, create breakouts, export session/logs, change verbosity.\
  All controls must be accessible and export actions trigger confirmations and audit log entries.
- **Live Feed:**\
  Displays all included agent responses; suppressed responses are visible in log but not main feed.
- **Accessibility:**\
  Full keyboard navigation, screen reader support, log export in multiple formats.

---

## **RBAC/ABAC Enforcement**

- **Roles:** user, admin, system
- **Attributes:** session, room, operation (create, add, remove, export, end)
- **Policy:**
  - Only user may create, end, or export sessions.
  - Agents/personas may only join/leave if user initiates.
  - External agent participation always visible/logged, no silent joining.
  - Core cannot access or mutate persona memory—must use MCP/Vault for data handoff.
- **Audit:**\
  Every join/leave, breakout, setting change, export, or suppression is logged.

---

## **Memory, Privacy, and User Control**

- **Session Data:**\
  All logs, feeds, agent actions, and settings are reviewable and exportable by the user.
- **Privacy:**\
  No session data is shared or exported except by explicit user action.
- **User Control:**\
  User controls all agent participation, breakout creation, log verbosity, and export/purge.

## **Breakout and Recovery Workflow**

- **Breakout Creation:**\
  User selects subset of participants, defines topic, launches breakout.\
  All actions/logs remain tied to parent session.
- **Recovery:**\
  Ended or archived sessions can be restored at user command—full session context, log, and participants.

## 6. Synapse — Secure External Gateway & Protocol Boundary

**Role:**\
Sole orchestrator and gatekeeper for all inbound/outbound traffic between Hearthlink, plugins, external LLMs, APIs, and web resources. Synapse enforces protocol boundaries, logs and mediates all traffic, and provides policy-driven controls for plugin sandboxing, manifest enforcement, and multi-system onboarding.\
All external access, plugin execution, and agent communications flow through Synapse and are routed through Core for context/logging.

---

## Technical Architecture

- **Traffic Router:**\
  All web/API/plugin/external traffic enters and exits via Synapse.\
  Session-aware, persona-aware routing; every request/response is linked to the responsible persona and operation.
- **Plugin/External Agent Management:**\
  All plugins/extensions must declare a manifest (capabilities, permissions, version, sandboxing requirements).\
  User approves/disapproves each new plugin/connection, triggering audit trail and risk scoring.
- **Benchmarking & Tiering:**\
  Every connection and external agent is assigned a performance tier and risk score, based on real-time usage, plugin activity, and benchmarking tools.
- **Sandboxing & Isolation:**\
  All plugin/external code runs in isolated sandboxed containers.\
  Synapse enforces resource constraints, permission boundaries, and termination policies.
- **Compliance & Audit:**\
  All traffic, plugin loads, manifest updates, and connection handshakes are logged and exportable.\
  High-level traffic summaries by connection; deep-dive logs available on demand.

---

## **Plugin Manifest Schema (Example)**

```
json
```

`{ "plugin_id": "summarizer-v2", "name": "Summarizer", "version": "2.0.1", "requested_permissions": ["read_documents", "write_notes"], "sandbox": true, "risk_score": 12, "approved_by_user": true, "manifest_signature": "sha256:...", "benchmarks": { "avg_response_ms": 430, "error_rate": 0.01 }, "audit_log": [ {"event": "approved", "by": "user", "timestamp": "..."}, {"event": "benchmark", "score": 15, "timestamp": "..."} ] }`

---

## **API Contracts**

- `POST /api/synapse/plugin/register` — Submit new plugin/extension manifest, validate, and await user approval.
- `POST /api/synapse/plugin/approve` — User approves/declines manifest (triggers audit log, risk scoring).
- `POST /api/synapse/connection/handshake` — Initiate or approve connection to new external service.
- `GET /api/synapse/traffic/summary` — Return summarized traffic logs per plugin/connection.
- `GET /api/synapse/traffic/logs` — Retrieve detailed logs (by plugin, session, or time window).
- `POST /api/synapse/benchmark/run` — Execute real-time benchmark/health check on plugin/external agent.
- `PATCH /api/synapse/plugin/:id/permissions` — Update permissions; triggers user review/approval.
- `POST /api/synapse/plugin/:id/revoke` — Revoke/remove plugin; logs action, cleans up sandbox/resources.

**All endpoints are audited, and every plugin/connection change triggers user notification and log entry.**

- **Plugin/Connection Dashboard:**\

- **Accessibility:**\
  Keyboard navigation, readable logs, and permission explanations.

## **RBAC/ABAC Enforcement**

- **Roles:** user, admin, system
- **Attributes:** plugin, connection, operation (approve, revoke, update, benchmark)
- **Policy:**
  - Only user may approve, update, or revoke plugin/connections.
  - Synapse enforces sandboxing/isolation—never runs plugin in-process.
  - All external traffic routed through Core and logged.
- **Audit:**
  - Every approval, permission update, benchmark, and revocation is logged with role, action, and timestamp.

---

## **Benchmarking, Risk, and Compliance**

- **Performance Tiers:**\
  Plugins/connections are assigned tiers (eg. “stable”, “beta”, “risky”) based on benchmarks, error rates, and user feedback.
- **Manifest Signing:**\
  All manifests require digital signature (user/dev team). Unsigned or mismatched manifests trigger warning and require user override.
- **Connection Policy:**\
  No plugin or external agent may open new connections without manifest declaration and user approval.
- **Traffic/Log Visibility:**\
  User controls traffic log verbosity (summary, detail, or off for performance).

---

## **User Control & Privacy**

- **Approval Flow:**\
  Every plugin or external agent must be user-approved before first execution.
- **Permission Review:**\
  All permission grants, upgrades, or revocations prompt user review and log the outcome.
- **Sandbox/Resource Limits:**\
  User can set/adjust plugin resource ceilings.
- **Export:**\
  All logs and manifests are exportable for compliance review.

---

**This section now fully specifies Synapse’s role, interfaces, security, user control, and logging—no summary, no omission.**

# 7. Sentry — Security, Compliance & Oversight Persona

**Role:**\
Security and compliance overseer for the entire Hearthlink ecosystem, providing adaptive threat detection, automated audit, user-friendly interventions, and full override capability (user always in control, with informed risk).

- Monitors and audits every action, boundary, session, and external connection.
- Performs real-time anomaly detection, plugin/multi-system threat modeling, and code change audit.
- User/admin can override any intervention with explicit warning and audit log. Sentry maintains monitoring and reports ongoing status.
- Provides real-time Risk Dashboard, Override Panel, and Anomaly Review Center.
- All audit, intervention, and override events are logged, timestamped, and exportable.

---

## Technical Architecture

- **Session/Flow Monitor:**\
  Tracks all user and agent actions, boundary crossings, plugin invocations, manifest updates, and external handshakes.
- **Risk Engine:**\
  Real-time analysis using rule-based, behavioral, and pattern-drift models. Each event/action is scored for risk, flagged if above threshold.
- **Override & Intervention:**\
  Any Sentry warning or block can be user-overridden, with detailed risk explanation.\
  Sentry logs every override and continues monitoring for escalation/fallout.
- **Plugin/Extension Auditing:**\
  All plugins/extensions are monitored for manifest changes, code drift, abnormal usage, or unsanctioned connections.
- **Benchmark & Kill Switches:**\
  Automated/manual controls for plugin/agent “kill,” quarantine, or whitelist, with impact report and rollback.
- **Audit Trail:**\
  Immutable, timestamped, and user-exportable log for all actions and overrides.

---

## **Sentry Risk Event Schema (Example)**

```
json
```

CopyEdit

`{ "event_id": "risk-5432", "event_type": "plugin_permission_escalation", "origin": "synapse", "plugin_id": "summarizer-v2", "risk_score": 89, "recommended_action": "block", "user_override": false, "timestamp": "2025-07-06T15:32:00Z", "resolution": null, "escalation_chain": [], "audit_log": [ {"action": "detected", "by": "sentry", "timestamp": "..."}, {"action": "user_reviewed", "by": "user", "timestamp": "..."} ] }`

---

## **API Contracts**

- `GET /api/sentry/audit` — Retrieve audit log (filter by type, time, session, risk score)
- `POST /api/sentry/override` — User/admin override a block/intervention (requires reason, triggers warning, logs action)
- `POST /api/sentry/kill` — Terminate/quarantine plugin/agent/connection
- `GET /api/sentry/dashboard` — Real-time risk status, threat map, override center
- `GET /api/sentry/anomaly-review` — List all recent flagged anomalies/events for review
- `PATCH /api/sentry/risk-config` — Update risk thresholds, escalation rules, whitelist/blacklist

---

## **UI/Component Contract (React/Typescript)**

```
typescript
```

`type SentryDashboardProps = { riskEvents: RiskEvent[] onOverride: (eventId: string, reason: string) => void onKill: (targetId: string) => void onExportAudit: () => void thresholds: RiskThresholds onThresholdUpdate: (thresholds: RiskThresholds) => void auditLog: AuditEvent[] }`

- **Risk Dashboard:**\
  Live list and timeline of all events, risk scores, overrides, and interventions.
- **Override Panel:**\
  User/admin can override any block/warning, must provide reason, and see likely risk/fallout.
- **Anomaly Review Center:**\
  View and annotate all flagged events. Confirm, escalate, or ignore each.
- **Kill Switch:**\
  Immediate quarantine/termination for plugins, agents, or connections, with full impact report and rollback.
- **Audit Export:**\
  Full export of all Sentry events, interventions, and overrides.
- **Accessibility:**\
  All controls keyboard/screen-reader accessible; risk explanations and audit logs human-readable and exportable.

---

## **RBAC/ABAC Enforcement**

- **Roles:** user, admin, system
- **Attributes:** event, type, operation (review, override, kill, export, config)
- **Policy:**
  - Only user/admin can override, kill, or configure risk thresholds.
  - Sentry cannot block user/admin access to logs or export.
  - Every action is logged, including ignored/escalated events.
- **Audit:**\
  All interventions, overrides, kills, and config changes are immutable and timestamped.

---

## **Threat/Override Model**

- **Default:**\
  Sentry blocks or warns on risk, shows explicit reason and suggested action.
- **Override:**\
  User/admin can always override, but must provide explicit reason.\
  Sentry tracks override, continues monitoring, and flags any further fallout.
- **Escalation:**\
  Multiple overrides or recurring risk events trigger escalation (optional notification, audit, or review required).
- **User Control:**\
  User can configure risk thresholds, override history, and kill-list directly from dashboard.

---

## **Compliance, Export & Privacy**

- **Compliance:**\
  Audit logs and interventions exportable for compliance.\
  Sentry never deletes audit events or blocks export.
- **Privacy:**\
  No personal/user data leaves system except by user-initiated export.
- **Export:**\
  All logs, risk events, overrides, and threat models exportable as JSON, CSV, or table.

---

# GEMINI.md: Hearthlink Project Overview

This document provides a comprehensive overview of the Hearthlink project, intended to serve as a guide for developers and contributors.

## Recent UI Updates (Codex ƒ+' Gemini)

- Hearthlink crest loader now standardized at 192px and shared via `HearthlinkLoadingSequence`.
- Startup screen (`src/components/UnifiedHearthlinkApp.tsx`) shows the crest sequence over the obsidian + stars background with the text ƒ?oHEARTHLINK / Initializing Multi-Agent Systemƒ??.
- Enhanced launcher (`src/components/EnhancedLaunchPage.tsx`) uses the same crest sequence in the center during loading.
- Hierarchical launcher (`src/components/launchpad/HierarchicalLaunchPage.tsx`) swaps from the same-sized crest loader to the static crest at load completion.
- Radial navigation hub (`src/components/mythtech/navigation/RadialNavigationModal.tsx`) centers the crest at the same 192px footprint for consistency across experiences.
  - **Refinements**: Implemented seamless "soft edge" design using inset shadows, removed "pop" by simplifying to single-phase opacity animation, and added "frosted" texture effect.

## Parallel UI Polish (Gemini ƒ+" Codex)

- Gemini completed: header alignment and grid spacing refinements on Alden Command Center; Orbitron font integrated.
- **Expanded Chat Layout v3**:
  - **Status**: Design defined (4-column grid), implementation pending/broken.
  - **Issue**: Previous implementation attempt resulted in syntax errors and failed build, despite initial success claims.
  - **Next Steps**: Claude to implement `ExpandedChat.tsx` following `expandedchat_handoff.md` spec.
- Codex in progress: final polish for Alden Command Center.
  - Visual polish: tighten ƒ?otech borderƒ?? rings/shadows on `MetricCard` and main panels (target subtle premium feel; e.g., reduce ring/shadow intensity) in `src/components/alden/AldenCommandCenter.tsx`.
  - Active states: ensure ƒ?oActiveƒ?? badge/glow on MetricCard pops without overpowering.
  - GlobalCommsStream: seamless sidebar background integration with main panel (`src/components/mythtech/tasks/GlobalCommsStream.tsx` as embedded).
  - Typography & density: audit font sizes/padding for high-density command-center feel (consider `text-3xl` vs `text-4xl`, `p-5/p-4` vs `p-6`); standardize uppercase tracking (`tracking-widest` for main headers, `tracking-wider` for subs).
  - Preserve Orbitron on headers/metrics; avoid ƒ?ocheap glowƒ??.

## Recent Backend Updates (GLM 4.6)

- **Cleanup & Optimization**:
  - Resolved 100+ compilation warnings in `src-tauri`.
  - Updated deprecated cryptographic APIs (`aes-gcm`, `generic-array`) to modern standards.
  - Removed unused imports and dead code across `alden`, `core`, and `mimic` modules.
  - Fixed critical stream consumption bug in `email_imap.rs`.
- **Feature Implementation**:
  - Implemented Alice's Deep Work session management in Rust backend (`src-tauri/src/alice.rs`).
  - Added corresponding Python implementation in `src/personas/alice.py` for analysis parity.
  - Added unit tests for Deep Work flow in `tests/test_persona_alice.py`.
  - **Test Coverage**:
    - Implemented comprehensive unit tests for `MemorySliceManager` (encryption, search, versioning).
    - Added extensive tests for `SecureVault` and `SecureKeyManager` (key rotation, input validation).
    - Achieved 100% pass rate on 66 backend unit tests.
- **Vault RAG Pipeline**:
  - `vault_rag_search` now decrypts AES-256-GCM memory slices in `src-tauri/src/vault/rag_engine.rs` and returns fully serialized `RagSearchResult` entries (`content`, `content_type`, `tags`, `similarity_score`, etc.) to `VaultBridge.searchSemantic`.
  - `src/components/vault/VaultCommandCenter.tsx` renders those plaintext contents/tags and similarity metadata, and gracefully falls back to `VaultBridge.searchMemoriesSemantic` when the front-end is still using the placeholder `query_embedding: []`.
- **DateTime Serialization Fix**:
  - Implemented `datetime_serde` utility for robust i64 <-> ISO 8601 String conversion.
  - Patched `Alden` module models (`Task`, `CalendarEvent`, etc.) to use this utility, resolving frontend parsing crashes.
  - Confirmed `Vault`, `Core`, `Alice`, and `Mimic` modules natively use ISO 8601 Strings, requiring no changes.
  - **Status**: Backend fully aligned with Frontend Date requirements.

## Project Overview

Hearthlink is a next-generation, local-first AI ecosystem designed to provide advanced, adaptive support for users with ADHD. It transforms the concept of a personal assistant into a proactive, intelligent partner that learns, adapts, and integrates with the user's digital life to enhance focus, manage executive function challenges, and optimize productivity.

**Core Technologies:**

- **Frontend:** React, TypeScript, Tailwind CSS, Emotion
- **Backend:** Rust (Tauri), Python (for legacy IPC and scripting)
- **Desktop Framework:** Tauri
- **AI/ML:** Ollama for local AI processing
- **Database:** SQLite (inferred from local-first architecture and `db_manager` in Rust code)
- **Testing:** Jest (unit/integration), Playwright (end-to-end)

**Architecture:**

Hearthlink is built on a sophisticated, multi-layered architecture that separates core intelligence from management systems and external integrations. It follows a local-first philosophy, ensuring that user data remains on the device.

- **Multi-Agent System:** The core of Hearthlink is a multi-agent system where specialized AI personas (Alden, Alice, Mimic) collaborate to provide holistic support.
- **Modular Design:** The backend is divided into several modules, including `alden`, `alice`, `mimic`, `vault`, `sentry`, `synapse`, and `core`.
- **Tauri Application:** Hearthlink is a Tauri application, using web technologies for the frontend and a Rust backend for performance and security.
- **Pure IPC Mode:** The application uses Tauri's Inter-Process Communication (IPC) for frontend-backend communication, avoiding the need for local HTTP servers.
- **Skill System:** Hearthlink features an extensible skill system that allows for the dynamic addition of new capabilities to the agents.

## Building and Running

### Prerequisites

- Node.js and npm
- Rust and Cargo
- Python 3.8+

### Installation

1.  **Clone the repository:**

    ```bash
    git clone https://github.com/WulfForge/Hearthlink.git
    cd Hearthlink
    ```

2.  **Install JavaScript dependencies:**

    ```bash
    npm install
    ```

3.  **Install Python dependencies:**
    ```bash
    pip install -r requirements.txt
    ```

### Development

- **Run the application in development mode:**

  ```bash
  npm run dev
  ```

  This will start the Tauri development server, which will build and launch the application.

- **Run the React frontend separately:**
  ```bash
  npm run dev:react
  ```
  This is useful for focusing on frontend development without rebuilding the entire Tauri application.

 ## Important Notes
 
 1. **Accessibility is mandatory** - These are errors, not warnings
 2. **Test keyboard navigation** - Tab through forms, press Enter on buttons
 3. **Screen reader users depend on this** - Label associations are critical
 4. **Don't touch backend files** - Stay in `src/components/**/*.tsx`
 5. **Verify frequently:**
    ```bash
    npx eslint "src/components/settings/SettingsPanelEnhanced.tsx" --rule 'jsx-a11y/*: error'
    ```
 
 ---
+
+## Handoff Suggestions for Gemini
+
+1. **Merge candidates**: `origin/consolidate-all-fixes` (Tauri v2 move, CI/workflow fixes, Rust/security stabilizations), `origin/feature/enterprise-monitoring` (multi-user, RBAC/ABAC, SIEM/monitoring modules plus docs), and `origin/work` (PersonaMemoryBridge integration/tests) are the highest-priority branches currently ahead of `main`. Evaluate CI/test results before landing but treat them as next in line.
+2. **Review `origin/NOV18` carefully**: It already layers most of the UI/agent doc dump against `main`. The diff adds thousands of agent skill files and a large React/Tauri overhaul, so confirm licensing/performance expectations and ensure the `src/components/OnboardingWizard.tsx`/equivalents behave before merging.
+3. **Avoid redundant merges**: `origin/NOV16`, `origin/October-Sprint`, `feature/enterprise-multi-user`, and similar branches duplicate commits already in `NOV18` or `feature/enterprise-monitoring`; merging them separately risks reintroducing conflicts without adding new work.
+4. **Local working tree note**: `config/agents/manifest.json`, `config/skills/registry.json`, and `src/components/OnboardingWizard.tsx` already have local edits on `NOV18`. Keep those changes committed/clean before merging anything into `main`.
+
 ## Ready to Start
 
 1. Read full details in: `GEMINI_ESLINT_TASKS.md`
 2. **START WITH TASK B.1 (ACCESSIBILITY) - THIS IS CRITICAL**
*** End Patch

Hearthlink-MarketResearch.md:318:Competitive Landscape Positioning: Hearthlink sits at an intersection of several product categories: personal AI assistant (like x.ai or Replika or MS 365 Copilot), multi-agent dev framework (like LangChain/CrewAI), and productivity software (like a PIM suite). This is both an opportunity and a challenge. The opportunity is to define a new category – “Personal AI Orchestration Platform” – and be a pioneer there. The challenge is facing indirect competition from each category: for example, Microsoft’s Copilot features will soon be in Office, handling emails and schedules with GPT-4 (albeit cloud-based) – that’s a strong competitor for user mindshare. Open-source peer projects like Flowise or GPT Engineer provide some automation too, but are narrower. Hearthlink’s edge would be its comprehensiveness and openness. To be feasible, Hearthlink might not initially compete head-on with enterprise offerings or fully mature solutions, but rather attract a dedicated user base that values its unique selling points. Those early successes could generate case studies (e.g., “Indie consultant saves 10 hours/week using Hearthlink AI”), which in turn could convince a broader audience. The team behind Hearthlink should also be mindful of trust – marketing the privacy/security angle to distinguish from big tech solutions, and demonstrating reliability to overcome the hesitation of using a relatively unknown tool for important tasks. Monetization and Sustainability: As an open-source project, one route to market is offering a managed service or premium version. For example, a “Hearthlink Pro” could be a subscription that includes easy cloud sync across devices, access to proprietary smaller models running locally for speed, or specialized persona packs for certain industries. Early adopters might contribute to the open-source, but mainstream users often come via a polished product even if under the hood it’s open-source. The viability will depend on if the team can either build a community (like many open-source projects do) or secure backing (perhaps partnerships with privacy-focused organizations or research grants, given the novel approach). In conclusion, Hearthlink’s market feasibility will hinge on focusing where it has clear value: individual users and small teams that want an integrated, private AI assistant. By delivering tangible productivity gains to those users and highlighting what makes it safer and more customizable than the alternatives, Hearthlink can carve out a sustainable niche. It might not immediately grab enterprise contracts away from established players, but it doesn’t need to – success can be found by becoming the go-to personal AI for power users, which can then expand outward.
Hearthlink-MarketResearch.md:375:In conclusion, by rapidly building its core features, polishing the user experience, and leveraging its unique values in privacy and persona-driven interaction, Hearthlink can increase its viability and distinctness in the market. The recommendations above aim to ensure that Hearthlink not only catches up to what competitors offer, but leapfrogs them in areas aligned with its vision – delivering a personal AI that is smart, trustworthy, and deeply integrated into the user’s life. With careful execution, Hearthlink can transform from a bold concept into a practical, beloved tool for its target users, thereby carving a lasting presence even as the agentic AI ecosystem grows around it. """
Memory Intelligence API - Unified interface for collaborative memory operations

Provides high-level APIs for personas to interact with the enhanced memory foundation:
- Shared insight creation and retrieval
- Collaborative pattern learning
- Cross-persona knowledge sharing
- Context-aware memory synthesis

References:
- vault/memory_foundation_schema.py: Memory foundation schemas
- HEARTHLINK_UNIFIED_DESIGN_FRAMEWORK.md: Layer 1 Memory Foundation

Author: Hearthlink Development Team
Version: 1.0.0
"""

import json
import uuid
from typing import Dict, Any, Optional, List, Union, Tuple
from datetime import datetime, timedelta
from dataclasses import asdict

from ..vault.vault import Vault
from ..vault.memory_foundation_schema import (
    MemoryFoundationManager, SharedInsightMemory, CollaborativeSessionMemory,
    CrossPersonaLearning, InsightType, CollaborationPattern,
    MemoryFoundationError, SharedInsightError, CollaborativeMemoryError
)
from ..main import HearthlinkLogger


class MemoryIntelligenceError(Exception):
    """Base exception for memory intelligence operations."""
    pass


class MemoryIntelligenceAPI:
    """
    High-level API for persona memory intelligence operations.

    This class provides the primary interface for personas to:
    - Share insights with other personas
    - Learn from collaborative patterns
    - Access relevant memory for current context
    - Contribute to cross-persona learning
    """

    def __init__(self, vault: Vault, logger: Optional[HearthlinkLogger] = None):
        """
        Initialize memory intelligence API.

        Args:
            vault: Vault instance for storage
            logger: Optional logger instance
        """
        self.vault = vault
        self.logger = logger or HearthlinkLogger("MemoryIntelligence")
        self.foundation_manager = MemoryFoundationManager(vault, self.logger)

    # === SHARED INSIGHT OPERATIONS ===

    def create_user_pattern_insight(self, user_id: str, discovering_persona: str,
                                  pattern_title: str, pattern_details: Dict[str, Any],
                                  confidence: float = 0.8, tags: List[str] = None) -> str:
        """
        Create insight about user behavior pattern discovered by a persona.

        Args:
            user_id: User identifier
            discovering_persona: Persona that discovered this pattern
            pattern_title: Brief description of the pattern
            pattern_details: Detailed pattern information
            confidence: Confidence in this pattern (0.0-1.0)
            tags: Optional tags for categorization

        Returns:
            str: Insight ID

        Example:
            insight_id = memory_api.create_user_pattern_insight(
                user_id="user123",
                discovering_persona="alice",
                pattern_title="Morning stress pattern",
                pattern_details={
                    "trigger": "work emails before coffee",
                    "symptoms": ["anxious responses", "hasty decisions"],
                    "intervention": "suggest coffee before email check",
                    "evidence": ["3 observed instances", "user confirmed pattern"]
                },
                confidence=0.9,
                tags=["stress", "morning_routine", "productivity"]
            )
        """
        try:
            content = {
                "pattern_details": pattern_details,
                "evidence_strength": "high" if confidence > 0.8 else "medium" if confidence > 0.6 else "low",
                "tags": tags or []
            }

            insight_id = self.foundation_manager.create_shared_insight(
                user_id=user_id,
                contributing_personas=[discovering_persona],
                insight_type=InsightType.USER_PATTERN,
                title=pattern_title,
                content=content,
                confidence_score=confidence
            )

            self.logger.info(f"Created user pattern insight: {pattern_title}",
                           extra={"insight_id": insight_id, "persona": discovering_persona})

            return insight_id

        except Exception as e:
            self.logger.error(f"Failed to create user pattern insight: {e}")
            raise MemoryIntelligenceError(f"Failed to create insight: {str(e)}") from e

    def validate_insight_from_experience(self, insight_id: str, validating_persona: str,
                                       user_id: str, validation_experience: Dict[str, Any],
                                       agreement_score: float) -> None:
        """
        Validate an existing insight based on persona's own experience.

        Args:
            insight_id: ID of insight to validate
            validating_persona: Persona providing validation
            user_id: User identifier
            validation_experience: Details of validating experience
            agreement_score: How much persona agrees with insight (0.0-1.0)

        Example:
            memory_api.validate_insight_from_experience(
                insight_id="insight-abc123",
                validating_persona="alden",
                user_id="user123",
                validation_experience={
                    "situation": "User seemed stressed during morning planning",
                    "applied_insight": "Suggested coffee break first",
                    "outcome": "User relaxed and made better decisions",
                    "confirms_pattern": True
                },
                agreement_score=0.95
            )
        """
        try:
            # First validate the insight
            self.foundation_manager.validate_shared_insight(
                insight_id=insight_id,
                validating_persona=validating_persona,
                validation_score=agreement_score,
                user_id=user_id
            )

            # Record the validation experience as additional context
            insight_data = self.vault.get_communal(insight_id, user_id)
            if insight_data:
                current_content = insight_data.get("content", {})
                validation_experiences = current_content.get("validation_experiences", [])
                validation_experiences.append({
                    "validating_persona": validating_persona,
                    "experience": validation_experience,
                    "agreement_score": agreement_score,
                    "timestamp": datetime.now().isoformat()
                })
                current_content["validation_experiences"] = validation_experiences

                # Update the insight with validation experience
                self.vault.create_or_update_communal(insight_id, {
                    **insight_data,
                    "content": current_content
                }, user_id)

            self.logger.info(f"Validated insight {insight_id} by {validating_persona}",
                           extra={"agreement_score": agreement_score})

        except Exception as e:
            self.logger.error(f"Failed to validate insight: {e}")
            raise MemoryIntelligenceError(f"Failed to validate insight: {str(e)}") from e

    def get_relevant_insights_for_context(self, user_id: str, requesting_persona: str,
                                        current_context: Dict[str, Any],
                                        max_insights: int = 5) -> List[Dict[str, Any]]:
        """
        Get insights relevant to current context for persona decision making.

        Args:
            user_id: User identifier
            requesting_persona: Persona requesting insights
            current_context: Current situation context
            max_insights: Maximum number of insights to return

        Returns:
            List of relevant insights with relevance scores

        Example:
            insights = memory_api.get_relevant_insights_for_context(
                user_id="user123",
                requesting_persona="alden",
                current_context={
                    "type": "task_planning",
                    "time_of_day": "morning",
                    "user_mood": "stressed",
                    "task_complexity": "high"
                },
                max_insights=3
            )
        """
        try:
            insights = self.foundation_manager.get_relevant_shared_insights(
                user_id=user_id,
                context=current_context,
                requesting_persona=requesting_persona
            )

            # Convert to API format with relevance scores
            formatted_insights = []
            for insight in insights[:max_insights]:
                relevance_score = self._calculate_insight_relevance(insight, current_context)
                formatted_insights.append({
                    "insight_id": insight.insight_id,
                    "title": insight.title,
                    "type": insight.insight_type.value,
                    "content": insight.content,
                    "confidence": insight.confidence_score,
                    "relevance": relevance_score,
                    "contributing_personas": insight.contributing_personas,
                    "validation_count": insight.validation_count
                })

            return formatted_insights

        except Exception as e:
            self.logger.error(f"Failed to get relevant insights: {e}")
            return []

    # === COLLABORATIVE PATTERN OPERATIONS ===

    def record_collaboration_success(self, user_id: str, participant_personas: List[str],
                                   collaboration_details: Dict[str, Any],
                                   user_satisfaction: float, effectiveness: float,
                                   duration_seconds: float) -> str:
        """
        Record successful collaboration pattern for future replication.

        Args:
            user_id: User identifier
            participant_personas: Personas involved in collaboration
            collaboration_details: Details of how collaboration worked
            user_satisfaction: User satisfaction score (0.0-1.0)
            effectiveness: Objective effectiveness score (0.0-1.0)
            duration_seconds: How long the collaboration took

        Returns:
            str: Session ID

        Example:
            session_id = memory_api.record_collaboration_success(
                user_id="user123",
              …59291 tokens truncated…sightMemory]) -> Dict[str, Any]:
        """Extract stress-related patterns."""
        stress_patterns = {
            "triggers": [],
            "indicators": [],
            "effective_interventions": []
        }

        for insight in insights:
            if "stress" in insight.title.lower() or insight.insight_type == InsightType.STRESS_INDICATOR:
                content = insight.content.get("pattern_details", {})
                stress_patterns["triggers"].append(content.get("trigger", ""))
                stress_patterns["indicators"].extend(content.get("symptoms", []))
                intervention = content.get("intervention", "")
                if intervention:
                    stress_patterns["effective_interventions"].append(intervention)

        return stress_patterns

    def _extract_productivity_patterns(self, insights: List[SharedInsightMemory]) -> Dict[str, Any]:
        """Extract productivity-related patterns."""
        productivity = {
            "peak_times": [],
            "optimal_conditions": [],
            "productivity_boosters": []
        }

        for insight in insights:
            if "productivity" in insight.title.lower() or insight.insight_type == InsightType.PRODUCTIVITY_PATTERN:
                content = insight.content.get("pattern_details", {})
                # Extract productivity information
                # This would be more sophisticated in a full implementation

        return productivity

    def _extract_learning_patterns(self, insights: List[SharedInsightMemory]) -> Dict[str, Any]:
        """Extract learning-related patterns."""
        learning = {
            "preferred_styles": [],
            "effective_methods": [],
            "struggle_areas": []
        }

        for insight in insights:
            if insight.insight_type == InsightType.LEARNING_PREFERENCE:
                content = insight.content.get("pattern_details", {})
                # Extract learning preferences
                # This would be more sophisticated in a full implementation

        return learning

    def _calculate_synthesis_confidence(self, insights: List[SharedInsightMemory],
                                      patterns: List[CollaborativeSessionMemory]) -> float:
        """Calculate confidence in the synthesis based on data quality and quantity."""
        if not insights and not patterns:
            return 0.0

        # Base confidence on number of high-confidence insights and effective patterns
        high_confidence_insights = len([i for i in insights if i.confidence_score > 0.8])
        effective_patterns = len([p for p in patterns if p.effectiveness_score > 0.7])

        # Simple confidence calculation
        confidence = min(1.0, (high_confidence_insights * 0.1 + effective_patterns * 0.15))

        return confidence

    def update_foundation_metrics(self, user_id: str) -> None:
        """Update memory foundation effectiveness metrics."""
        try:
            self.foundation_manager.update_memory_foundation_metrics(user_id)
        except Exception as e:
            self.logger.error(f"Failed to update foundation metrics: {e}")


def create_memory_intelligence_api(vault: Vault, logger: Optional[HearthlinkLogger] = None) -> MemoryIntelligenceAPI:
    """
    Factory function to create memory intelligence API.

    Args:
        vault: Vault instance

Table 1: Feature and architecture comparison of Hearthlink and other agentic AI systems. (Hearthlink features marked as ƒ?oplannedƒ?? or ƒ?odesignedƒ?? are drawn from documentation; many are not yet fully implemented in code.)

Hearthlinkƒ?Ts design envisages rich collaboration between its personas and external agents, but it is still at the design stage for multi-agent orchestration. github.com

**Summarizing Hearthlink MarketResearch.md**

payload.message:
Hearthlink is framed in the Market Viability Plan (see `Hearthlink-MarketResearch.md:1-160`) as a **multi-agent, persona-based productivity ecosystem** rather than a single chatbot: a Tauri/Rust-backed desktop shell hosts React/Tailwind UIs while three core personas (Alden the executive assistant, Alice the behavioral coach, and Mimic the persona generator) are orchestrated by a Core “session conductor,” supported by Vault (encrypted per-persona memory), Synapse (safe external/plugin gateway), and Sentry (security/audit overseer). The document highlights the **local-first architecture**, strict memory isolation, and user-controlled learning updates as key differentiators for privacy-sensitive ADHD users.

From that same plan (`Hearthlink-MarketResearch.md:200-560`) the pitch stresses that Hearthlink’s viability hinges on packaging this architecture as a **complete personal AI platform**: integrated UI tabs (calendar, email, task/knowledge dashboards), a memory-and-learning stack that logs insights per persona, a permissioned plugin/agent ecosystem, and a friendly experience that adapts to cognitive styles. It positions Hearthlink as a “personal AI orchestration platform” that combines proactive coaching, adaptive memory, and secure automation—aiming to appeal to power users (and later enterprises) who want an all-in-one, privacy-first assistant rather than stitching disparate tools together.

Hearthlink is framed in the Market Viability Plan (see `Hearthlink-MarketResearch.md:1-160`) as a **multi-agent, persona-based productivity ecosystem** rather than a single chatbot: a Tauri/Rust-backed desktop shell hosts React/Tailwind UIs while three core personas (Alden the executive assistant, Alice the behavioral coach, and Mimic the persona generator) are orchestrated by a Core “session conductor,” supported by Vault (encrypted per-persona memory), Synapse (safe external/plugin gateway), and Sentry (security/audit overseer). The document highlights the **local-first architecture**, strict memory isolation, and user-controlled learning updates as key differentiators for privacy-sensitive ADHD users.

From that same plan (`Hearthlink-MarketResearch.md:200-560`) the pitch stresses that Hearthlink’s viability hinges on packaging this architecture as a **complete personal AI platform**: integrated UI tabs (calendar, email, task/knowledge dashboards), a memory-and-learning stack that logs insights per persona, a permissioned plugin/agent ecosystem, and a friendly experience that adapts to cognitive styles. It positions Hearthlink as a “personal AI orchestration platform” that combines proactive coaching, adaptive memory, and secure automation—aiming to appeal to power users (and later enterprises) who want an all-in-one, privacy-first assistant rather than stitching disparate tools together.
